Award.AwardTitle: Louisiana Mathematics Masters in the Middle (LaM3)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: The Louisiana Mathematics Masters in the Middle (LaM3) project is a collaborative partnership involving the University of Louisiana at Lafayette's College of Education and College of Sciences, Lafayette Parish School System, Iberia Parish School System, Vermilion Parish School System, and the Allen J. Celestine Foundation. Twenty exceptionally qualified mathematics teachers recruited from the three partner school districts are completing graduate coursework leading to the Louisiana Elementary Mathematics Specialist Certification, which signifies the ability to provide instructional leadership in mathematics. This Master Teacher Fellowship project is anchored in intensive content and pedagogical graduate courses and in engaging practicum that allows the participants to maximize their pedagogical potential. An objective of the project is to leverage the knowledge and skills of this talented mathematics teaching corps to foster, nurture, and unearth the hidden or unmet potential in students who are often underexposed to high-quality mathematics teaching. The project is 1) studying the effects of further strengthening mathematical content and pedagogical knowledge of exceptional mathematics teachers in Louisiana and 2) examining the extent to which the participants can accelerate the mathematical savvy and proficiency of students who possess hidden or unmet potential. The Master Teachers are establishing professional learning communities in their schools and mentoring preservice students who are preparing to become middle school mathematics teachers. The project further attempts to accentuate the value of LaM3 participants by chronicling changes in their peers' pedagogical practices that are attributable to participants' instructional leadership and describing empirical accounts of pre-service teachers' seminal experiences under the mentorship of LaM3 participants.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Louisiana Mathematics Masters in the Middle (LaM3) project engendered intellectual merit through 1) studying the effects of further strengthening mathematical content and pedagogical knowledge of exceptional mathematics teacher participants and 2) examining the extent to which participants accelerated and maintained the mathematical confidence of middle school students who possess Hidden or Unmet Potential in mathematics. The project further accentuated the value of LaM3 Master Teacher Fellows by examining their peers’ perceptions of pedagogical practices attributable to LaM3 Master Teacher Fellows’ instructional leadership. As noted in the Louisiana Mathematics Masters in the Middle (LaM3) External Evaluation Report conducted by RMC research, LaM3 Master Teacher Fellows improved significantly in the domains of Preparedness to Teach Mathematics, Confidence, Ability, and Support for Teaching Mathematics, Facilitating Improvements in Teaching through Use of Research, Promoting the Use of Assessments and Data, Improving Outreach and Collaboration, Creating a Collaborative Culture, and Accessing and Using Research.

LaM3 Master Teacher Fellows were provided the space to apply their acquired knowledge in their daily instruction and also with students from other schools and partner districts through the project’s Advancing Mathematics Excellence (AME) camp.  Students involved in the AME camps were enrolled in high-needs schools with varied levels of mathematics proficiency. A major goal of the AME camp was to utilize the expanded mathematical capacity Master Teacher Fellows to advance students' mathematical knowledge and pique their curiosity about the nature of STEM endeavors. RMC research utilized three sub-scales from the Math Self-Efficacy and Math Self-Concept Subscales of the Programme for International Student Assessment (PISA) to evaluate AME camp goals: PISA Math Self-Concept (five items) to assess student beliefs about mathematical ability; PISA Math Interest (four items) to assess the enjoyment of mathematics tasks, and PISA Math Anxiety (five items) to assess worry about mathematics classes, work, and grades. RMC’s analyses of student samples revealed students maintained high levels of self-concept for mathematics, interest for mathematics, and generally low anxiety about mathematics through their AME camp experiences. This is important to note due to an abundance of research indicating opposite effects for a large number of middle school mathematics students.  

LaM3 Master Teacher Fellows also demonstrated instructional leadership through developing a series of practitioner mini-conferences centered on improving mathematics instruction. Teachers from local school districts who attended the four Mini-conferences were invited to complete satisfaction surveys about their attendance. The survey was developed and examined by RMC Research with the intent of gathering participant feedback. Respondents from each group praised the hands-on, experiential nature of activities and the usefulness and adaptability of materials presented. Respondents indicated that ideas and activities shared at the conference could be immediately integrated into classrooms with students at different grade levels as well as at different proficiency levels within a grade.

Because the (LaM3) project is rooted in coursework and experiences inextricably linked to best practices in mathematics professional development noteworthy results are now included in forthcoming manuscripts. The broader impact of the project, as espoused in prior and forthcoming dissemination via manuscripts and professional presentations, further details the domino effects of providing mathematical boosts for LaM3 Master Teacher Fellows, which helped to advance students’ mathematical knowledge and broadened their vision and inquisitiveness about applications of mathematics.
